channel.title: 317 Packet Documentation
channel.description:
317 Packet Documentation: [b]Incoming Packets (Client - Server)[/b]
[code]Packet 0: Idle packet Size: 0 Payload: No Payload
Packet 3: Focus Change packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 4: Regular Chat packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 36: Unknown Size: 4 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 45: Flagged Account Data packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 57: Item on NPC packet Size: 8 Payload: Unsigned Word ( a ), Unsigned Word ( a ), Unsigned Word Big Endian, Unsigned Word ( a )
Packet 60: Unknown Size: 8 Payload: Long
Packet 86: Camera Angle packet Size: 4 Payload: Unsigned Word, Unsigned Word ( a )
Packet 95: Update Chat packet Size: 3 Payload: Unsigned byte, Unsigned byte, Unsigned byte
Packet 98: Walk On Command packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 101: Character Design Screen packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 103: Command packet Size: Variable Payload: String (varies in size)
Packet 121: Unknown Size: 0 Payload: No Payload
Packet 126: PM Message packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 150: Unknown Size: 0 Payload: No Payload
Packet 164: Regular Walk packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 165: Unknown Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 185: Clicking Most Buttons packet Size: 2 Unsigned int
Packet 188: Add Friend packet Size: 8 Payload: Long
Packet 202: Idle Logout packet Size: 0 Payload: No Payload
Packet 208: Bank X Amount of Items Part 2 packet Size: 4 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 210: New Area Loading packet Size: 4 Payload: Integer
Packet 214: Change Item Places packet Size: 5 Payload: Unsigned Word Big Endian ( a ), Unsigned Byte ( c ), Unsigned Word Big Endian
Packet 215: Remove Friend packet Size: 8 Payload: Long
Packet 218: Unknown Size: 10 Payload: Long, Unsigned byte, Unsigned byte
Packet 226: Unknown Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 236: Pickup Item packet Size: 6 Payload: Unsigned Word Big Endian, Unsigned Word, Unsigned Word Big Endian
Packet 238: Unknown Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte
Packet 241: Mouse Clicks packet Size: 4 Payload: Integer
Packet 248: Map Walk packet Size: 1 Payload: Unsigned byte[/code]
Total number of packets documented: [b]30[/b]
For any other information needed, go to the [url=http://rswiki.gyrat.in/index.php?title=Category:Packet:317]RSWiki[/url] documentation.

item.title: 317 Packet Documentation
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

Packet 36 is sent if the player’s walking queue size is more than or equal to 92. If it is, their walking queue size is reset and an integer with a value of 0 is sent to the server. Possibly to prevent players being able to click ridiculously far away through a bug etc

Packet 60 sends a name entered into the “Enter name” chatbox interface as a long.

Packet 121 appears to be sent when a new region is loaded but the region load/construction packet hasn’t been sent to the client, or when a player updating packet has been sent to the client.

Packet 150 appears to be sent when more than 98 regions have been loaded.

Packet 165 appears to be the same as packet 238 in that it checks the value of an integer that is never changed before sending a collection of numbers to the server. Probably more removed anti-cheating stuff.

Packet 208 sends a value entered into the “Enter amount” chatbox interface as an integer.

Packet 218 is the packet sent to the server when a client reports a player.
First, the name of the reported player is sent as a long. Then, the type of report is sent as an unsigned byte and whether the player was muted via the report screen is sent as an unsigned byte (1 for yes and 0 for no).

Packet 226 appears to be called when more than 1235 regions have been loaded in a game session.

Packet 238 checks if an integer is more than 160 and then sends a set value but the integer is never changed from 0 so this is probably old code from anti-cheating stuff that’s been removed. If the integer was more than 160 then the packet would send a byte containing the value “96”.

That should clear up all the "unknown"s.

Read full topic

anIntArray552

Search that. Sizes are in there. I’m guessing for the actual packet’s opcode you would have to manually edit them in the client class. Kinda be hell since there is a lot of them and you have to keep track of all of the opcodes and which ones you are switching it to and such.

item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

The Wanderer:

I believe it is PacketConstants. Why would you, though?

Unrenamed, and a while ago, while I was finding the ID’s, I remembered at least three classes.

Why wouldn’t you? Jagex scrambles their packets all the time. Although it’s not the best way to stop cheat clients, it will still be a good addition to my altered login protocol.

item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:86, topic:317150”][quote author=The Wanderer link=topic=413688.msg3720709#msg3720709 date=1313913416]

Could somebody please confirm that there are 30 client > server packets?
Good job btw.

For the 317 client there appears to be more than 30 packets.
http://rswiki.gyrat.in/index.php?title=317_Protocol#Client_-.3E_Server_Packets
I counted 53. Not sure how accurate that table is either, although I would be willing to bet it is quite accurate.
[/quote]
up to 255 iirc[/quote]
cuz its stored as a byte. Not every single number has a packet assigned to it, at least I don’t believe so.

Read full topic
